title: How to properly use 'due to' in a sentence - Quora

response.answer_text: In its strictest sense, a “due” (noun) is a debt or an outcome that is to be fulfilled by someone or something; the debt or outcome is also “due” to the subject (adjective). In most cases, as noted by others, it is a functional synonym for “because of”, as you are attributing the effect to a cause - “The success of this project was due [accredited] to the collaborative effort of the team”. But “because of” doesn’t work in sentences such as “A sum of £100 is due [owed] to the society treasurer”, or “His train was due [supposed] to arrive at 10:40”. So, when trying to use it in a sentence, see if it can be replaced with “thanks to”, “owed to”, or “supposed to”, and you’ll have a good idea of whether it works.

‘Due to’ is a causal connective, much like ‘because’. You could substitute it in place of ‘because of’. The tone of due to is a little bit more authoritative, as if you are going to be talking about facts or factors affecting an outcome, rather than just explaining things in a more basic spoken way. Eg Due to his failure to comply, he was sacked. He was sacked, due to his failure to comply. The tone is slightly different is ‘He was sacked because of his failure to comply. The second still sounds like ‘official information’ but is a more verbal form.
